pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw:
Honestly I'd prefer if the text and title methods weren't defined on PhasePlot.  At some level we're intentionally limiting the API while also making it easy to access the matplotlib primitives. That said if others are ok with including it I'm not going to put my foot down.

The xlim and ylim methods are fine, although the histogram does not get recalculated.  You may want to take a look at how I implemented these methods in yt-3.0.
content.html:
Honestly I'd prefer if the text and title methods weren't defined on PhasePlot. At some level we're intentionally limiting the API while also making it easy to access the matplotlib primitives. That said if others are ok with including it I'm not going to put my foot down.

The xlim and ylim methods are fine, although the histogram does not get recalculated. You may want to take a look at how I implemented these methods in yt-3.0.

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw: @ngoldbaum : Do you prefer a different method of setting the title and placing text on a PhasePlot?  Aren't these two functions which are defined for PlotWindow objects?
content.html: Nathan Goldbaum : Do you prefer a different method of setting the title and placing text on a PhasePlot? Aren't these two functions which are defined for PlotWindow objects?

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw:
Like I said above, by directly manipulating the matplotlib primitives.

Some issues that this implementation will have:

* uses the default matplotlib fonts rather than the one we specify in self.font_properties.

* will get overrided if a plot is recreated somehow, for example by calling any function decorated with `invalidate_plot`.

Both those issues are solvable but IMHO not worth the effort given that we make the matplotlib primitives available.
content.html:
Like I said above, by directly manipulating the matplotlib primitives.

Some issues that this implementation will have:

  • uses the default matplotlib fonts rather than the one we specify in self.font_properties.

  • will get overrided if a plot is recreated somehow, for example by calling any function decorated with invalidate_plot.

Both those issues are solvable but IMHO not worth the effort given that we make the matplotlib primitives available.

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw:
Ah OK, I didn't realise that the architecture logic was designed so that manipulation of the plots would be via the matplotlib primitives. If that preserves the font type and also   means that called decorated functions doesn't overide changes then that sound like a better approach. Let's put this PR on ice for now and I can look again at the logic at least for the title functions.

I'll also have a look at how the limits are set in 3.0 and may update these helper functions in that case.
content.html:
Ah OK, I didn't realise that the architecture logic was designed so that manipulation of the plots would be via the matplotlib primitives. If that preserves the font type and also means that called decorated functions doesn't overide changes then that sound like a better approach. Let's put this PR on ice for now and I can look again at the logic at least for the title functions.

I'll also have a look at how the limits are set in 3.0 and may update these helper functions in that case.

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw:
@ngoldbaum I implemented the set_title, text etc with the matplotlib primitives this morning. It's a little tricky because just doing something like

Ph_Plot = PhasePlot(...)
plot = Ph_Plot.plots
ax = plot.axes

So now I have the primitive if I do 
ax.set_xlabel("My X Axis") 

This changes the label but the font is the default - is that the expected behaviour? In order to get the YT fonts I also had to pass in the font_properties object which isn't obvious. 

The xlim and ylim functions also aren't as straight forward to match to the ones you have implemented in 3.0 because the function prototype for create_profile has changed in 3.0 to include an extreama argument which is not available in 2.x. Recreating the profile with changed extremes seems a bit trickier as a result - you know more about this than me so there may still be a straight forward approach to recreate the profile with the new extremes?
content.html:
Nathan Goldbaum I implemented the set_title, text etc with the matplotlib primitives this morning. It's a little tricky because just doing something like

Ph_Plot = PhasePlot(...) plot = Ph_Plot.plots ax = plot.axes

So now I have the primitive if I do ax.set_xlabel("My X Axis")

This changes the label but the font is the default - is that the expected behaviour? In order to get the YT fonts I also had to pass in the font_properties object which isn't obvious.

The xlim and ylim functions also aren't as straight forward to match to the ones you have implemented in 3.0 because the function prototype for create_profile has changed in 3.0 to include an extreama argument which is not available in 2.x. Recreating the profile with changed extremes seems a bit trickier as a result - you know more about this than me so there may still be a straight forward approach to recreate the profile with the new extremes?

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw:
I agree that it's a little cumbersome.  Honestly, I'm coming around to having `set_[xyz]title` functions.  That said, you'll need to make a few changes to this PR before I'd be willing to sign off.

1. Rather than defining these functions on the `PhasePlot` class, it makes more sense to define these function on the `ImagePlotContainer` class (`PhasePlot`'s superclass).  That way these functions will be available for the `PlotWindow` classes.  You'll need to change the way you're iterating over the plots in these functions.  Use `for f in self.plots` instead of `for f in self.profile.field_data` since `PlotWindow` plots don't have a `profile` attribute.

2. I would probably call them `set_[xyz]label` rather than `set_[xyz]title`.  This should remove ambiguity from the plot title which you can set via the `set_title` function.  Also perhaps it should be `set_colorbar_label` instead of `set_zlabel`.

3. As you metioned, you need to set the fonts for the labels using the `font_properties` attribute of the plot.

4. The labels and x and y limits will need to be cached somehow and then reapplied when the plot is recreated in the `_setup_plots` function.  Take a look at how I do that in the `set_zlim` or `set_axes_unit` functions as examples.

Once that's done I'm happy to port these functions to yt-3.0 since I think they're generally useful.  Just today @desika asked how to adjust the plot labels on IRC.

As for the second point you raise, you basically have two options.  Either leave the functions as they are right now, or backport the `extrema` keyword for `create_profile` from yt-3.0 to yt-2.x.  I believe that will be straightforward.  I'll leave it up to you about how to handle that.
content.html:
I agree that it's a little cumbersome. Honestly, I'm coming around to having set_[xyz]title functions. That said, you'll need to make a few changes to this PR before I'd be willing to sign off.

  1. Rather than defining these functions on the PhasePlot class, it makes more sense to define these function on the ImagePlotContainer class (PhasePlot's superclass). That way these functions will be available for the PlotWindow classes. You'll need to change the way you're iterating over the plots in these functions. Use for f in self.plots instead of for f in self.profile.field_data since PlotWindow plots don't have a profile attribute.

  2. I would probably call them set_[xyz]label rather than set_[xyz]title. This should remove ambiguity from the plot title which you can set via the set_title function. Also perhaps it should be set_colorbar_label instead of set_zlabel.

  3. As you metioned, you need to set the fonts for the labels using the font_properties attribute of the plot.

  4. The labels and x and y limits will need to be cached somehow and then reapplied when the plot is recreated in the _setup_plots function. Take a look at how I do that in the set_zlim or set_axes_unit functions as examples.

Once that's done I'm happy to port these functions to yt-3.0 since I think they're generally useful. Just today Desika Narayanan asked how to adjust the plot labels on IRC.

As for the second point you raise, you basically have two options. Either leave the functions as they are right now, or backport the extrema keyword for create_profile from yt-3.0 to yt-2.x. I believe that will be straightforward. I'll leave it up to you about how to handle that.

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw:
I think the text label should also be a positional argument.  You should also make sure to set the font using `font_properties`.

This function can stay attached to the `PhasePlot` class rather than being moved up to `ImagePlotContainer` since the `PlotWindow` classes have `annotate_text` to take care of this.
content.html:
I think the text label should also be a positional argument. You should also make sure to set the font using font_properties.

This function can stay attached to the PhasePlot class rather than being moved up to ImagePlotContainer since the PlotWindow classes have annotate_text to take care of this.

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw:
Can you explain a bit more about this change?  At a bare minimum, I don't think the format string should change.

Is the issue you were having that you can't fully control the filename? I agree that's an issue with the current implementation in the 2.x branch, but FWIW it looks like that's been fixed in yt-3.  I can do `plot.save(image.png)` and it saves the plot to disk with the name `image.png`.

You might want to try backporting the save function from the yt-3.0 branch.
content.html:
Can you explain a bit more about this change? At a bare minimum, I don't think the format string should change.

Is the issue you were having that you can't fully control the filename? I agree that's an issue with the current implementation in the 2.x branch, but FWIW it looks like that's been fixed in yt-3. I can do plot.save(image.png) and it saves the plot to disk with the name image.png.

You might want to try backporting the save function from the yt-3.0 branch.

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw: Yeah the problem I found was that I couldn't fully control the filename, the change made that much simpler. Before the change, even when I did something like plot.save(blabla) it attached a load of other things to the filename (fieldnames) which was a nuisance. Now it only does that if Name is None. yt-3.0 may well have fixed that and if that's the case then I can have a look and backport - it's likely a straight forward switch.
content.html: Yeah the problem I found was that I couldn't fully control the filename, the change made that much simpler. Before the change, even when I did something like plot.save(blabla) it attached a load of other things to the filename (fieldnames) which was a nuisance. Now it only does that if Name is None. yt-3.0 may well have fixed that and if that's the case then I can have a look and backport - it's likely a straight forward switch.

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw:
The main issue I have is that this breaks the understanding that `name` is a prefix unless fully qualified with a recognized image format suffix.  For example, the following snippet:

```python
ph = PhasePlot(ds.all_data(), 'density', 'temperature', 'cell_mass')
ph.save('phase')
```

Should save `phase_2d-Profile_density_temperature_cell_mass.png` to disk.
content.html:
The main issue I have is that this breaks the understanding that name is a prefix unless fully qualified with a recognized image format suffix. For example, the following snippet:

ph = PhasePlot(ds.all_data(), 'density', 'temperature', 'cell_mass')
ph.save('phase')

Should save phase_2d-Profile_density_temperature_cell_mass.png to disk.

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw:
There is a common superclass for `PhasePlot` and `PlotWindow`, `ProfilePlot` is it's own thing.  One could probably move a lot of the save logic from `PhasePlot` and `PlotWindow` into the superclass.

The real issue is the lack of testing for `PhasePlot` and `ProfilePlot`.
content.html:
There is a common superclass for PhasePlot and PlotWindow, ProfilePlot is it's own thing. One could probably move a lot of the save logic from PhasePlot and PlotWindow into the superclass.

The real issue is the lack of testing for PhasePlot and ProfilePlot.

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw: As a first pass, it's probably fine to just have the ``save`` functions of all the plotters be identical code.  If it's easy, ``save`` could be moved to the superclass of ``PlotWindow`` and ``PhasePlot``, which is ``ImagePlotContainer``.  @john_regan, is this something you'd be willing to take on in this PR?
content.html: As a first pass, it's probably fine to just have the save functions of all the plotters be identical code. If it's easy, save could be moved to the superclass of PlotWindow and PhasePlot, which is ImagePlotContainer. John Regan, is this something you'd be willing to take on in this PR?

pullrequest.title: Added a number of helper routines to PhasePlot

content.raw:
I have tested this and it works great.  Profiles can be modified as advertised with `set_xlim()`, `set_ylim()`, and `add_text()`;  plot_window objects as well as profiles can be modified with `set_xlabel()`, `set_ylabel()`, and `set_colorbar_label()`.  I think in a future PR, we should add the set_xlim() and set_ylim() functionality to all plot_window plots if possible, but aside from my comment below, this is good to go.  We should definitely port this to 3.0.

Nice work, @john_regan.
content.html:
I have tested this and it works great. Profiles can be modified as advertised with set_xlim(), set_ylim(), and add_text(); plot_window objects as well as profiles can be modified with set_xlabel(), set_ylabel(), and set_colorbar_label(). I think in a future PR, we should add the set_xlim() and set_ylim() functionality to all plot_window plots if possible, but aside from my comment below, this is good to go. We should definitely port this to 3.0.

Nice work, John Regan.
